I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to India for the Railway Sector Investment Program.1 
 
2.  The proposed investment program will increase the capacity of the existing rail network 
to  handle  the  traffic  demand  necessary  to  sustain  the  country's  economic  growth  by  (i) 
increasing the capacity of the physical rail infrastructure through electrification and doubling of 
rail tracks on critical routes; (ii) increasing the efficiency of existing infrastructure usage through 
the  introduction  of  modern  signaling  systems;  and  (iii)  improving  operational  and  financial 
efficiency through institutional  (and particularly accounting) reform. This will (i) reduce fuel 
consumption and enhance energy efficiency; (ii) reduce pollution; (iii) enhance railway safety; 
(iv) increase line capacity, benefitting consumers and producers of goods and services through 
the provision of timely and efficient transport services and lower logistics costs; and (v) improve 
staff productivity.2  
 
II.  THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  The growth rate of the Indian economy has been close to 8% in the last 6 years; while 
this is expected to continue for several years. India’s transport infrastructure needs further 
investment to meet the country’s growth demand. The Government of India’s Eleventh Five 
Year Plan (FY2007/08–FY2011/12) highlights the need for an efficient transportation system to 
effectively increase productivity and competitiveness in the world market. The development of 
various transport modes needs to be integrated to build an efficient, sustainable, safe, and 
regionally  balanced  transportation  system.  Railways  make  up  a  significant  part  of  India’s 
transport sector—in FY2009/10, railways carried 7.5 billion passengers and 888 million tons (t) 
of freight. The railways’ share, particularly of freight transport, has gone down steadily over the 
past few decades (from 89% in FY1950/51 to 30% in FY2007/08). 
 
4.  One of the most widespread constraints facing railway operations is the capacity of high-
density railway routes. The railway trunk routes comprise just 16% of the network but carry 
more than 50% of the traffic. The speed of freight trains on Indian Railways has stagnated at 
around 25 kilometers (km) per hour. Passenger services are also slow. Accidents per million 
train-km have been steadily reduced, from 5.5 per million train-km in FY1960/61 to 0.2 in 
FY2008/09. The operating ratio  improved from 91.0% in FY2004/05 to 75.9% in FY2007/08, but 
was  90.5% in FY2008/09. Critical efficiency parameters have improved, such as the net t-km 
per  wagon  day  (from  2,574  in  FY2003/04  to  3,539  in  FY2007/08)  and  the  net  t-km  and 
passenger-km per employee (from 0.69 in FY2004/05 to 1.01 in FY2008/09). However, there is 
room for further improvement. 
 
5.  The Indian Railways Vision 20203 estimates that an investment of around Rs14,000 
billion (about $310 billion) is needed for FY2010/11–FY2020/21. Indian Railways would be able 
to generate about 64% of the investment required for FY2010/11–FY2020/21 through internal 
generation and extra budgetary resources, including public–private partnerships. The remaining 
36% would need to be provided through gross budgetary support from the central government. 
                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided project preparatory assistance. ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance to 
India for Preparing the Railway Sector Investment Program. Manila. 
3   Ministry of Railways, Government of India. 2009. Indian Railways Vision 2020. New Delhi.

2 
Indian Railways needs to generate more funds through its operations to finance the needed 
expansion.  Together  with  capital  investment  to  augment  the  railway  network  capacity, 
accounting  reform  can  facilitate  greater  commercialization  of  railway  operations,  thereby 
increasing revenue generation. The Indian Railways Vision 2020 highlights that critical elements 
of the plan include (i) removal of infrastructural bottlenecks, (ii) creation of adequate capacity, (iii) 
design  and  delivery  of  highly  efficient  market-driven  services,  (iv)  safety  and  reliability  of 
operations, and (v) building institutional and organizational capacity.  
 
6.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB)-financed Railway Sector Improvement Project4 
formulated a detailed reform program and provided support for implementation of the key reform 
measures, especially accounting reform; this is most critical for better financial governance and 
management, and will lead to overall efficiency enhancement of Indian Railways. It was also 
recognized by all parties that accounting reform that makes the costs and revenues of railway 
services  and  operations  transparent  is  a  prerequisite  for  successful  implementation  of 
subsequent reforms. As assessed in the ADB sector assistance program evaluation (SAPE),5 
progress on implementation of reforms has been mixed. Indian Railways implemented some of 
the envisaged reforms.6 Private sector participation was substantially increased, especially in 
the operation of container trains and terminals. Separating core and noncore businesses was 
started by creating subsidiaries to run several noncore businesses as separate business activity 
centers. Computerization was undertaken on a massive scale to provide better services, and 
increase the commercial orientation of Indian Railways. Other envisaged reforms, such as 
making concession of loss-making branch lines, are by themselves not realistic while some 
efforts were made. The accounting reform has been slow, but steady progress has been made, 
and continued ADB support is needed. Substantial progress has been made in putting in place 
the prerequisites for implementation of the new accounting systems—such as standardized 
computerization—with  completion  targeted  for  2012.  As  recommended  by  the  SAPE,  new 
support is essential to continue implementation of the accounting reforms. 
 
7.  The Railway Sector Improvement Project reform program was overly ambitious, and 
sought to implement several major reforms in a relatively short timeframe and in a large, 
complex  organization.  A  focused  approach  on  the  accounting  system  is  considered  more 
appropriate and effective, as this is the core of all reform measures to enhance Indian Railways’ 
overall operational efficiency. However, the reform process did allow for wider dialogue within 
Indian Railways, as well as wider government circles, on the need for reform. The importance of 
accounting reform has been accepted and incorporated in Indian Railways’ own reform program 
(Indian Railways Vision 2020) and in the government’s Eleventh Plan (FY2007/08–FY2011/12).  
Accounting reform implementation is now being monitored by the Planning Commission, which 
has facilitated a continuing dialogue on the sector development between ADB and the Ministry 
of Railways (MOR). The detailed institutional strengthening action plan was agreed with MOR 
as set out in the framework financing agreement (FFA).7 
 
8.  While  investments  under  the  investment  program  are  a  small  subset  of  the  total 
investment required  under Indian  Railways  Vision  2020,  they  underline  the  very  nature of 
projects  that  the  vision  proposes  to  address:  capacity  enhancement,  connectivity,  and 
environmental sustainability. Investment in physical infrastructure under the investment program

includes: (i)  doubling  about  840 km  of (a)  the  Daund–Gulbarga  section (224 km), (b) the 
Sambalpur–Titlagarh section (182 km), (c) the Raipur–Titlagarh section (203 km), and (d) the 
Hospet–Tinaighat section (201 km); and (ii) electrification of the Pune–Wadi Guntakal section 
(641 km). Two of the projects are in the eastern states of Chhattisgarh and Orissa, while the 
others are mainly in the states of Maharashtra and Karnataka. Some of these are located in 
remote areas of the country that are rich in minerals and related industries. These routes and 
electrification (i) are also along the Indian Railways’ high density corridors, such as the “Golden 
Quadrilateral” that connects Chennai, Kolkata, Mumbai, and New Delhi; and (ii) connect ports 
and provide hinterland access. Finally, the lines carry heavy traffic such as ore, coal, and 
cement, which are best carried by rail. The modal shift of bulk goods from road to rail would 
reduce carbon emissions, and would possibly be eligible for carbon credits. 
 
9.  Transport infrastructure development is high priority for the government, making ADB’s 
strategy  of  reducing  poverty  through  infrastructure-led  growth  especially  relevant.  ADB’s 
continued support for the railways will help from an environmental perspective, and is in line 
with the country partnership strategy (2009–2012) for India,8 in terms of supporting inclusive 
and  environmentally  sustainable  growth.  The  investment  program  has  been  designed  in 
coordination with development partners to ensure wide geographic coverage and avoid overlaps, 
and continues ADB support for institutional strengthening of MOR, with a focus on accounting 
reform in parallel with capacity augmentation of existing railway lines. Lessons from the ongoing 
project were incorporated, and SAPE recommendations taken into account, e.g., enhancing the 
bid document to address more than 500 cost items, and engaging a general consultant to 
strengthen  project  implementation  programming  capacity.  Project  readiness  is  substantially 
advanced, e.g., the bid documents have been approved for issuance in 2011. 
  
10.  The  FFA  provides  details  of the roadmap,  strategic  context,  policy  framework,  and 
investment  program.  The  MFF  is  the  modality  best  suited  for  the  proposed  large-scale 
investment  program.  It  provides  for  ADB  to  enter  into  a  sustained  partnership  with  the 
government  for  a  long-term  investment,  with  larger  and  multiple  contracts  in  parallel  with 
continued support for railway efficiency improvement. All projects to be financed under the 
investment program have already been appraised. The use of an MFF allows the government 
and ADB to focus on institutional strengthening and project implementation, and to provide an 
optimal amount of timely financing by arranging contract packages in specialized components 
and/or a larger size, which stimulates more competition and increased participation by qualified 
contractors. It also opens the possibility of exploring cofinancing opportunities in subsequent 
tranches, with the government financing a larger portion, as financing products for projects that 
reduce carbon emission are emerging (e.g., Global Action for Reconciling Economic Growth 
and Environmental Preservation by the Japan Bank for International Cooperation). 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The investment program will improve the transport network and promote greater mobility 
that supports sustainable socioeconomic development in the country by developing an energy-
efficient, safe, reliable, affordable, and environment-friendly railway system along corridors with 
heavy bulk freight traffic. 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
12.  Railway improvement component. The investment program will double-track about 
840 km of rail routes and electrify 640 km of rail routes along high density corridors. The double 
                                                
8  ADB. 2009. Country Partnership Strategy: India, 2009–2012. Manila.

4 
tracking work will build a second track alongside the existing rail route, with associated signaling 
and electrical work. Project management consultants will be engaged as the Engineer at the 
contract level. A general consultant will be engaged to manage the overall investment program, 
including (i) providing advice on scheduling and critical path analysis, (ii) external monitoring of 
safeguard implementation, and (iii) supporting the executing agency in subsequent submission 
of periodic financing requests (PFRs) to ADB. 
 
13.  Institutional  efficiency  enhancement  component.  The  component  will  provide 
equipment and support to push forward the implementation of the new accounting architecture 
developed  with  ADB  support,  and  undertake  other  activities  in  support  of  the  institutional 
strengthening action plan (footnote  5) agreed with MOR. The new accounting systems, in 
synchronization  with  the  Government  Accounting  Standards  Advisory  Board,  will  be 
implemented  in  at  least  one  zone  under  the  investment  program,  and  will  be  further 
implemented in all zones of Indian Railways. Consultants engaged for accounting reform and 
general consultancy will identify the required equipment and procurement timing. 
 
14.  Clean  Development  Mechanism  component.  Implementation  support,  including 
provision  of  smoke  and gas  analyzers,  will  be  provided to  MOR for  (i)  monitoring  carbon 
emission reductions (CERs) and fulfilling the requirements for continued CER generation, based 
on  a  methodology  to  be  developed  with  ADB  technical  assistance,9 and  (ii)  other  Clean 
Development Mechanism (CDM) activities.

16.  The government has requested an MFF in an amount of up to $500 million from ADB's 
ordinary capital resources to help finance a part of the investment program. The MFF will 
consist of several tranches, subject to the government's submission of related PFRs, execution 
of the related loan and project agreements for each tranche, and fulfillment of terms and 
conditions and undertakings set forth in the FFA. The government has provided ADB with (i) the 
reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based 
lending facility based on these terms and conditions, and (ii) an undertaking that these choices 
were its independent decision and not made in reliance on any communication or advice from 
ADB.  For  each  tranche  under  the  MFF,  ADB  loan  proceeds  will  be  passed  on  by  the 
government to MOR, or through MOR, to Rail Vikas Nigam Limited (RVNL) under general 
budgetary financing arrangements. 
 
17.  The financing plan is in Table 2. The government will finance the remaining cost of 
$644.6 million equivalent, or about 56.3% of the total cost, including land acquisition, taxes and 
duties, remuneration of counterpart staff, office accommodation, interest and financing charges

long-term contract packages under the investment program. Each tranche will finance slices of

Each contract package is time-sliced in line with the indicative tranching plan. Table 3 provides 
the indicative schedule of the subsequent tranches based on the financial projection for each

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
21.  To enhance competition in procurement, contracts are packaged to allow bidders to 
submit multiple contracts at once with discounts. A general consultant is engaged to manage 
the overall investment program and provide technical advice on implementation scheduling with 
critical path analysis based on international best practice. Environmental considerations were 
enhanced by providing tree planting along the railways in addition to mandatory government 
tree planting. A modern signaling and telecommunication system will be provided that will 
enhance safety and environmental considerations such as light-emitting diode (LED) signals for 
good visibility and use of solar panel systems in all non-electrified areas as primary means of 
power supply. 
 
22.  A preliminary study indicated that the potential exists for the investment program to 
register CER credits with the CDM, due to substantial (0.9 million t) annual carbon emission 
reductions as a result of the modal shift from vehicular traffic along project corridors. Technical 
assistance will be provided separately along with the investment program to pursue CER credits 
and enhance Indian Railways’ CDM activities, including possible registration under the United 
Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
23.  The economic assessment12 was carried out in accordance with ADB's Guidelines for 
the Economic Analysis of Projects.13 The program will enhance capacity to meet the anticipated 
traffic demand and avoid diversion of incremental goods traffic onto the road network, which 
would result in increased transport costs. The economic internal rate of return ranges from 
15.6% to 20.1% for individual projects, indicating that the proposed investment program is 
economically viable. A sensitivity analysis tested the effects of possible negative changes in the 
key parameters that determine the program’s costs and benefits. This analysis indicates that the 
program’s economic viability would remain satisfactory even under adverse scenarios. 
 
                                                
12 Economic and Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
13 ADB. 1997. Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. Manila.

7 
24.  The financial assessment (footnote 12) was undertaken on an incremental basis using 
the discounted cash flow method, and calculating the internal rate of return of the program. The 
existing  single-line  railway  sections  are  operating  at  or  above  capacity;  without  capacity 
augmentation, they will not be able to carry the projected incremental traffic. The financial 
internal rate of return ranges from 12.9% to 15.9%, which is above the average cost of capital 
(7.9%). Sensitivity and risk analyses indicate that the investment program’s financial internal 
rate  of  return  is  robust  under  adverse  conditions.  Based  on  the  financial  projections  and 
financial evaluation, the program is considered both financially viable and sustainable. 
 
C.  Governance 
 
25.  Institutional.  RVNL  is  primarily  a  project  delivery  organization.  The  administrative 
control rests with MOR. RVNL has sufficient capacity to implement the program, which will be 
supported by the general consultant for the overall program scheduling and coordination, in 
addition to the project-specific project management consultants for construction supervision. 
 
26.  Financial management. RVNL has satisfactory project financial accounting capacity 
and knowledge of ADB disbursement procedures. All finance units of the project implementation 
units will be staffed before project commencement. The project accounts will be audited by the 
statutory auditor. MOR and RVNL will establish and maintain separate project records and 
accounts to identify the financing resources received and expenditures, ensuring an adequate 
audit trail. RVNL has a quarterly internal audit which is reviewed by the audit committee. The 
statutory auditor appointed by the government's Office of Comptroller and Auditor General will 
annually  audit  the  project  accounts  and  related  financial  statements  in  accordance  with 
international auditing standards. All recommendations of financial management assessment will 
be  implemented  during  the  investment  program  implementation  such  as  reporting 
standardization, strengthening project audit, and assessment of budget and actual expenditure 
for better budgeting and control. 
 
27.  Procurement  and  anticorruption. RVNL has a chief vigilance officer to handle all 
grievances including those relating to procurement. The Central Vigilance Commission, through 
its Chief Technical Examiners Organization, conducts systematic analysis and monitoring for 
compliance with procurement procedures and rules as well as issues guidance and instructions 
to  prevent  any  irregularities.  The  independent  safety  commissioner  will  undertake  a  final 
technical  audit  before  commissioning.  Contracts  financed  by  ADB  will  use  a  procurement 
process and bidding documents that follow ADB’s policies and include a policy statement on 
avoiding corrupt practices. The government will publish information relating to the investment 
program— including business opportunities, and information on procurement of goods, works, 
and consulting services—on RVNL and MOR websites. RVNL will also make available to ADB 
on request copies of internal audit reports. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to 
date) was explained to and discussed with the government, MOR, and RVNL. The specific 
measures are described in the FAM (footnote 11).  
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
 
28.  The railway will traverse Andhra Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Karnataka, Maharashtra, and 
Orissa.  According  to  the  government’s  Human  Development  Report  2001, 14 the  human 
development index for Maharashtra (0.523) and Karnataka (0.478) are higher than the national 
level of 0.472, while Andhra Pradesh (0.416), Chhattisgarh, and Orissa (0.404) are lower than 
the national level. About 64% of the people living in the five states reside in rural areas; most 
                                                
14  Government of India. National Planning Commission. 2001. National Human Development Report. New Delhi.

8 
derive their livelihood from agriculture and labor. Poverty is particularly acute in the rural areas. 
According to 2005 government estimates, the proportion of the rural population living below the 
official poverty line in Orissa (46%), Chhattisgarh (41%), and Maharashtra (31%) are above the 
national  average  (28%).  The  poverty  and  social  assessment  (PSA)  surveyed  11,297 
households and held 125 focus group discussions, participated in by men and women; the 
majority  stated  that  the  investment  program  will  increase  economic  and  employment 
opportunities  by  improving  linkages  to  markets,  production  centers,  and  public  and  social 
service facilities. Approximately 21 million people living in the areas influenced by the program 
will experience direct and indirect economic benefits brought about by the proposed investment, 
and about 5,400 person-years of work will be created for laborers during construction.15 
 
29.  Gender. Data from 2009 indicate the average gender development index in the five 
states as 0.586, close to the national figure of 0.590. The gender development indexes for 
Maharashtra (0.677) and Karnataka (0.611) are above that of India, while the indexes for 
Andhra Pradesh (0.574), Chhattisgarh (0.542), and Orissa (0.524) are below the national level. 
A  total  of  91  focus  group  discussions  were  undertaken  with  914  women  from  different 
socioeconomic groups. Women stated that the investment will benefit them, as increased train 
reliability  and  frequency  will  facilitate  industrial  development  and  economic  growth.  The 
participation of both men and women has been ensured during project planning and will also be 
ensured during implementation. MOR established the Railway Women’s Welfare Organization 
in 1962, which has successfully contributed to women’s empowerment by increasing the self-
sufficiency of women. The same effects for women are expected to be attained under this 
investment. The bidding documents provide clauses designed to ensure that all civil works 
contractors  comply  with  applicable  labor  laws;  do  not  employ  child  labor;  encourage  the 
employment of the poor, particularly women; and do not offer different wages to men and 
women, particularly for work of equal value. The nongovernment organization responsible for 
resettlement plan implementation will employ a gender expert to ensure implementation of 
contracts. The expert will also train poor women to upgrade their livelihood skills, and conduct 
gender and child labor awareness campaigns. 
 
30.  HIV and AIDS. Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, and Maharashtra are all noted to have a 
high prevalence of HIV/AIDS by the National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) and have been 
conducting HIV sentinel surveillance since 1998 as part of NACO’s National AIDS Control 
Program. All five states traversed by the railway have their own state AIDS control or prevention 
society and are committed to tackle HIV/AIDS, undertaking a multipronged and multisectoral 
approach in prevention and control; programs include mass media campaigns, adolescence 
education,  and  awareness  building  in  women’s  self-help  groups,  and  improving  access  to 
testing  facilities.  The  states  also  collaborate  closely  with  other  development  partners  in 
prevention and treatment efforts. Chhattisgarh and Orissa have a low prevalence of HIV/AIDS, 
but intense prevention and communication programs are ongoing. MOR has an AIDS control 
cell in MOR and its operational zones, and has adopted a wide range of national policies for HIV 
control since 1997. The focus of the cell is to improve awareness among all employees and 
others  associated  with  the  Indian  Railways  community  and  introduce  HIV/AIDS training to 
medical and paramedical staff. 
 
31.  Based on the PSA, there is no risk that the investment program will increase HIV/AIDS 
incidence. Contractors will carry out HIV/AIDS awareness for their laborers at work sites and 
this will be monitored by the general consultant during project implementation. In addition, with 
the State AIDS Control Society, NACO, and other public health agencies, the nongovernment 
                                                
15 Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
organizations  responsible  for  implementing  the  resettlement  plan  will  carry  out  HIV/AIDS 
information campaigns in communities in areas influenced by the program. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
32.  Environmental impact. There are no environmentally sensitive features in the areas 
affected  by  the  proposed  investment,  and  the  program  has  been  categorized  as  B  in 
accordance with ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). Initial environmental examinations 
prepared for all the projects show that the environmental impacts associated with establishment 
of double tracks, including embankment construction, are minor, with most impacts likely to 
occur during the construction stage. Recommended mitigation measures will be implemented 
under the environmental management plan and monitored under the environmental monitoring 
plan. The general consultants will conduct a training program to strengthen the capacity of 
RVNL officials to address environmental concerns, including supervising implementation of the 
environmental management and monitoring plans. An environmental assessment and review 
framework  has  been  prepared  to  guide  the  implementation  of  environment  safeguard 
requirements for the investment program and subsequent tranches. 
 
33.  Land acquisition and resettlement. The investment program is categorized as A in 
accordance with ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement. Six resettlement plans were prepared in 
accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement; the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 (amended 
in 1984); and the National Rehabilitation and Resettlement Policy (2007). According to the 
project census, 3,945 persons will be affected by the projects, out of which 76 households will 
be physically displaced and 344 economically displaced. The total resettlement budget for the 
program is Rs135,033,578. Compensation rates for the loss of land and structures, shifting 
assistance, income restoration assistance, and additional support for vulnerable groups are 
provided in the resettlement framework and resettlement plans. Meaningful consultation and 
information disclosure were undertaken during the preparation of resettlement plans, including 
with (i) project-displaced persons and (ii) the general public through the ADB website. If any 
changes  or  additional  land  requirements  or  involuntary  resettlement  impacts  are  identified 
during implementation, a related resettlement plan will be prepared or modified according to the 
applicable laws referred to in the resettlement plan. ADB’s prior approval will be obtained before 
further implementation of the relevant section of the subproject. 
 
34.  Impact on indigenous peoples. The investment program is classified as category B in 
accordance with the ADB Safeguard Policy Statement. Scheduled tribes account for 31.8% of 
the total population in Chhattisgarh, 16.6% in Orissa, 8.9% in Maharashtra, 6.6% in Karnataka, 
and 6.6% in Andhra Pradesh. The tribal population is scattered and not concentrated in any 
particular project areas, and interacts freely with the outside community. The study undertaken 
during  investment  program  preparation  did  not  show  any  difference  in  impact  between 
indigenous and non-indigenous groups in the project locations. The PSA survey confirmed that 
the socioeconomic impacts of the investment program will not differ significantly for tribal groups 
compared with the remainder of the population. In addition, meaningful consultations were 
conducted  with  both  primary  and  secondary  stakeholders  to  obtain  a  comprehensive 
perspective on the investment program and its impacts, and to obtain an estimate of losses that 
they would suffer and to develop ways to mitigate those losses. Special provisions have been 
made under the resettlement plans to address impacts on indigenous peoples. An indigenous 
peoples planning framework was prepared to address any unanticipated impacts on indigenous 
peoples during the implementation of existing or additional projects. If any significant impacts on 
indigenous peoples are identified, an indigenous peoples plan will be prepared and submitted to 
ADB for approval.

10 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
35.  The  key  risks  are  delays  in  implementation  (Table  4).  Other  risks  and  mitigating 
measures are summarized in the risk assessment and risk management plan.16 The integrated 
benefits and impacts are expected to outweigh the costs. 
 
Table 4: Key Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Safeguard  (i) Due diligence will be based on the final location survey; (ii) the adverse impacts of land 
compliance  acquisition, and social and environmental impacts will be mitigated through engineering measures; 
(iii) before commencing construction, a due diligence mission will be fielded to ensure compliance; 
and (iv) a project management consultant and general consultants will be engaged to help ensure 
full compliance with safeguard requirements during implementation. 
Project  (i) Advance actions have been made for high implementation readiness; (ii) contracts will packaged 
implementation to attract qualified contractors; (iii) the bill of quantity will take into account the complex character of 
railway projects; and (iv) a general consultant will be engaged to oversee the coordination and 
programming of the overall investment program, in addition to conventional subproject-level specific 
project management consultants. 
Institutional  A progress is made of accounting systems enhancement in synchronization with Government 
strengthening  Accounting Standards Advisory Board: (i) new accounting systems have been developed, and 
actions  prerequisite standardized computerization substantially progressed; (ii) the appointment of firms or 
agencies to implement the new accounting systems is being finalized; and (iii) close monitoring will 
be undertaken by the apex body of the Government of India for implementation. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES 
 
36.  The Government of India, MOR, and RVNL have assured ADB that implementation of 
the investment program shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning 
anticorruption  measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and 
disbursement as described in detail in the FAM and loan documents. 
 
37.  The government, MOR, and RVNL have agreed with ADB on certain undertakings for 
the MFF, which are set forth in the FFA. Specific covenants agreed by the government, MOR, 
and RVNL with respect to individual tranches under the MFF will be set forth in the loan 
agreement and project agreement for the respective tranches. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
38.  I am satisfied that the proposed multitranche financing facility would comply with the 
Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board 
approve the provision of loans under the multitranche financing facility in an aggregate principal 
amount not exceeding $500,000,000 to India for the Railway Sector Investment Program from 
ADB's ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance with ADB's 
London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility,  and  such  other  terms  and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the framework financing 
agreement presented to the Board. 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President
